13114D1E06C440B1A9650EB70B0B027E.description: LARW1.C.28: draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

48396F00FCBA4FAE8652D7833BD74766.description: LARW1.C.26: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the usefulness of each source in answering the research question; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citations

02FD854B88D74557961011C16AAFED0B.description: LARW1.C.25: conduct short, as well as more sustained, research projects to answer questions (including self-generated questions) or solve problems; narrow or broaden inquiries when appropriate; synthesize subjects, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

97C47586AB954FBFA78D8020C30C2418.description: LARW1.C.24: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

7D128D9A77824E329FE42E18EDAA6FE8.description: LARW1.C.23: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

37BB6416CAEB4C9397D07D74B273F705.description: LARW1.B.19: read and comprehend informational texts in the grades ninth through tenth text complexity band proficiently, by the end of ninth grade

D36778FAA8364FEBBE8688B1CC65FDC9.description: LARW1.B.18: analyze documents of historical and literary significance (e.g., Washington's Farewell Address, the Gettysburg Address, Roosevelt's Four Freedoms Speech, King's "Letter from Birmingham Jail," Nelson Mandela's Nobel Peace Prize Speech, The Universal Declaration of Human Rights), including how they address related themes and concepts

C8B564A44B59405C8921D6145F2986A5.description: LARW1.B.17: delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify false statements and fallacious reasoning

7D11BBA60B734246ACD9E8628819103C.description: LARW1.B.15: analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter)

E5B862E3B5F8434C96B3AE5009659443.description: LARW1.B.14: analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter)

DA436EA13FB04330BCBB87928D40BDFC.description: LARW1.B.13: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in an informational text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone (e.g., how the language of a court opinion differs from that of a newspaper)

05272C2D8E0D4A7CAE69774BEC1EA5EE.description: LARW1.B.12: analyze how the author of an informational text unfolds an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which the points are made, how they are introduced and developed, and the connections that are drawn between them

708CD0CA576D4C038F007F2D40D61F0A.description: LARW1.B.11: determine a central idea of an informational text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text

4A7A215D98E1484BA5D84BA0E69895D4.description: LARW1.B.10: cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what an informational text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text

47CE4AE0CADD4FA3B56F74FC9BEE9CE5.description: LARW1.A.9: read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the ninth through tenth grades text complexity band independently and proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range, by the end of ninth grade

1874FD14BCDC487DAB199C92D4E81AA8.description: LARW1.A.6: analyze a particular point of view or cultural experience reflected in a work of literature from outside the United States, drawing on a wide reading of world literature

FA75B7C66905483C8A784A39FC915286.description: LARW1.A.5: analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure a literary text, order events within it (e.g., parallel plots), and manipulate time (e.g., pacing, flashbacks) create such effects as mystery, tension, or surprise

09FD4C93212E40E792F9259DA230C6E9.description: LARW1.A.4: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a literary text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone (e.g., how the language evokes a sense of time and place; how it sets a formal or informal tone)

E4092F5424994B93BB5B692CBEBA2739.description: LARW1.A.3: analyze how complex characters (e.g., those with multiple or conflicting motivations) develop over the course of a literary text, interact with other characters, and advance the plot or develop the theme

BD6373971386446498EBFD9EA28ACABA.description: LARW1.A.2: determine a theme or central idea of a literary text and closely analyze its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text

50B706669D4A481390156F111436C680.description: LARW1.A.1: cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the literary text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text
